title: How to Fix a Dryer That Will Not Start

steps.headline: Check the cord for signs of damage.
steps.description: Are there any sections of the cord where lose wires have melted the insulation? Is the plug disconnected from the wiring in any way? If so, the problem is likely the cord.

steps.headline: Buy a new cord.
steps.description: Replacement parts can be ordered online or purchased at some stores. Check the manual or search the model number online for recommendations on compatible cords.

steps.headline: Replace the cord.
steps.description: Unplug the power cord from the wall. Find where the power cord connects to the dryer and unplug it. Plug the new cord in where they old one had been connected.

steps.headline: Find the lid switch.
steps.description: The lid switch signals that the door is closed. It should be an oblong hole opposite the door. It will be aligned so that a rod on the inside of the door will fit into it. Because this part takes a lot of wear and tear, it is prone to break.

steps.headline: Inspect the lid switch.
steps.description: You can often get a good sense, just from appearance and touch, whether the lid switch is broken. The switch should be level with the top panel that it is on. It is broken if it is not flush with the surface of the panel. Touch the lid switch to see if the spring underneath is functioning properly. If you press down on the lid switch and it does not give or spring back into place, it is probably broken.

steps.headline: Review the instruction manual.
steps.description: Because of variations in design, it is important to review the instruction manual to see recommendations for how to replace your lid switch. Alternatively search online for “remove lid switch” with the model number and serial number for your dryer.

steps.headline: Remove the lint screen.
steps.description: Generally, you will need to remove the lint screen to open the dryer. Pull out the lint screen. Then, use a screw driver to unscrew the lint screen housing panel that the lint screen fits into. After the screws are removed, pull out the housing panel. Always unplug the dryer before opening it up.

steps.headline: Remove the top.
steps.description: Place putty knives under the left and right side of the top panel of the dryer. Lift simultaneously on both ends to pick up the cabinet top. Move it out of the way.

steps.headline: Unlock the door switch harness.
steps.description: Once you open the top of the dryer, you should be able to find a pair of wires connecting to the door. There should be a locking mechanism where two large plugs connect wires in the control panel to the wires in the door. Disconnect these two parts of the locking mechanism. You might need to insert a slot screwdriver between the two plugs to release the locking mechanism.

steps.headline: Remove the lid switch.
steps.description: There should be two screws on either side of the lid switch, inside the door. Use a screw driver to unscrew these and pull out the lid switch.

steps.headline: Replace the lid switch.
steps.description: Put your replacement lid switch where the old lid switch had been. Screw it into place. Connect the wires on the lid switch to the locking mechanism that you disconnected earlier.

steps.headline: Put the dryer back together.
steps.description: Lower the top of the dryer back down. Screw the lint trap back into place. Plug the dryer back in.

steps.headline: Open the control panel.
steps.description: The control panel is the interface with all the buttons on it. Unscrew the screws holding it into place, or, on some models, unscrew the back panel behind it to access controls. Set the control panel someplace where it will be safe. As with most dryer repairs you should unplug your dryer before beginning this. Skip this method if you have an electronic interface. Start switch malfunctions generally occur when the start button is an older, mechanical model.

steps.headline: Remove the start switch.
steps.description: The start switch is the button that you press to start the dryer. There should be wires on the back of it that are connected to the start switch with metal parts. Use pliers to pull on the metal connectors, rather than the wires themselves, to disconnect the wires from the start switch. Take note of which wires insert into which parts of the start switch. You will need to correctly reconnect these wires to the appropriate spots.

steps.headline: Use an ohmmeter to test connectivity.
steps.description: Insert the ohmmeter into the start switch and measure at a resistance of R X 1. The ohmmeter should record a reading of infinity. Now press down and hold on the start switch. The ohmmeter should now record a connectivity of zero. If the ohmmeter correctly records that the start switch has connectivity, then you should stop here. If it does not give correct readings, you should replace it.

steps.headline: Remove the old start switch.
steps.description: You should pull the knob out from the front. Then remove the hardware of the start switch from the back. On the back, there might be a locking tab connecting the start switch to the panel. Press down on it with a screw driver and pull out to release the start switch.

steps.headline: Insert a new start switch.
steps.description: Place the new start switch where the old one was. Connect the wires correctly to the places where they had previously been connected on the old model. After the switch is inserted, you put the control panel back on and plug the dryer in.

text: Changing the Power Cord Check the cord for signs of damage. Are there any sections of the cord where lose wires have melted the insulation? Is the plug disconnected from the wiring in any way? If so, the problem is likely the cord. Buy a new cord. Replacement parts can be ordered online or purchased at some stores. Check the manual or search the model number online for recommendations on compatible cords. Replace the cord. Unplug the power cord from the wall. Find where the power cord connects to the dryer and unplug it. Plug the new cord in where they old one had been connected. Replacing the Lid Switch Find the lid switch. The lid switch signals that the door is closed. It should be an oblong hole opposite the door. It will be aligned so that a rod on the inside of the door will fit into it. Because this part takes a lot of wear and tear, it is prone to break. Inspect the lid switch. You can often get a good sense, just from appearance and touch, whether the lid switch is broken. The switch should be level with the top panel that it is on. It is broken if it is not flush with the surface of the panel. Touch the lid switch to see if the spring underneath is functioning properly. If you press down on the lid switch and it does not give or spring back into place, it is probably broken. Review the instruction manual. Because of variations in design, it is important to review the instruction manual to see recommendations for how to replace your lid switch. Alternatively search online for “remove lid switch” with the model number and serial number for your dryer. Remove the lint screen. Generally, you will need to remove the lint screen to open the dryer. Pull out the lint screen. Then, use a screw driver to unscrew the lint screen housing panel that the lint screen fits into. After the screws are removed, pull out the housing panel. Always unplug the dryer before opening it up. Remove the top. Place putty knives under the left and right side of the top panel of the dryer. Lift simultaneously on both ends to pick up the cabinet top. Move it out of the way. Unlock the door switch harness. Once you open the top of the dryer, you should be able to find a pair of wires connecting to the door. There should be a locking mechanism where two large plugs connect wires in the control panel to the wires in the door. Disconnect these two parts of the locking mechanism. You might need to insert a slot screwdriver between the two plugs to release the locking mechanism. Remove the lid switch. There should be two screws on either side of the lid switch, inside the door. Use a screw driver to unscrew these and pull out the lid switch. Replace the lid switch. Put your replacement lid switch where the old lid switch had been. Screw it into place. Connect the wires on the lid switch to the locking mechanism that you disconnected earlier. Put the dryer back together. Lower the top of the dryer back down. Screw the lint trap back into place. Plug the dryer back in. Repairing a Start Switch Open the control panel. The control panel is the interface with all the buttons on it. Unscrew the screws holding it into place, or, on some models, unscrew the back panel behind it to access controls. Set the control panel someplace where it will be safe. As with most dryer repairs you should unplug your dryer before beginning this. Skip this method if you have an electronic interface. Start switch malfunctions generally occur when the start button is an older, mechanical model. Remove the start switch. The start switch is the button that you press to start the dryer. There should be wires on the back of it that are connected to the start switch with metal parts. Use pliers to pull on the metal connectors, rather than the wires themselves, to disconnect the wires from the start switch. Take note of which wires insert into which parts of the start switch. You will need to correctly reconnect these wires to the appropriate spots. Use an ohmmeter to test connectivity. Insert the ohmmeter into the start switch and measure at a resistance of R X 1. The ohmmeter should record a reading of infinity. Now press down and hold on the start switch. The ohmmeter should now record a connectivity of zero. If the ohmmeter correctly records that the start switch has connectivity, then you should stop here. If it does not give correct readings, you should replace it. Remove the old start switch. You should pull the knob out from the front. Then remove the hardware of the start switch from the back. On the back, there might be a locking tab connecting the start switch to the panel. Press down on it with a screw driver and pull out to release the start switch. Insert a new start switch. Place the new start switch where the old one was. Connect the wires correctly to the places where they had previously been connected on the old model. After the switch is inserted, you put the control panel back on and plug the dryer in.
